flow.context: Amy Taylor is VP of Operations (Oregon) at Meredith Lodging — the parent behind Cannon Beach Vacation Rentals (CBVR). She owns turn standards, inspections, housekeeping, and maintenance quality across their coastal Oregon portfolio (80+ homes claimed). They run Track/TravelNet as their PMS with no Breezeway detected — RapidEye plugs directly into Track. Oregon State grad with multi-site ops background. Strongest hook: Sam works with similar coastal VR operators and RapidEye integrates with the exact PMS her team uses daily. Fallback contacts if Amy redirects: Aaron Linfoot (President), Ashley Kingman (GM), Rachel Beardslee (Dir of Ops).

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Amy — I work with a few other vacation rental operators who run coastal portfolios pretty similar to Meredith's. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye — have you heard the name tossed around?
opener.note: Warm, casual tone. Feet-up energy. Don't rush — let the question hang after you ask it.

heard_yes.label: THEY'VE HEARD OF US
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone like you on the operations side. What'd you hear?
heard_yes.note: Let her talk. Whatever she says, bridge into discovery. Don't correct or pitch yet.

heard_no.label: HAVEN'T HEARD OF US
heard_no.say: Ha — I guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call is —
heard_no.note: Deliver this lightly, then roll straight into the pain trigger. No pause here.

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again later this week? Maybe Thursday or Friday morning?
bad_timing.note: Offer specific days. Lock a callback if possible. Don't grovel.

reschedule.label: CALLBACK LOCKED
reschedule.say: Perfect — I'll try you then. Really appreciate it, Amy. Talk soon.
reschedule.note: Log the callback time immediately. Don't push for more. You got a win.

guarded_response.label: GUARDED — PERMISSION ASK
guarded_response.say: Yeah totally — I mean it is a cold call, I'll be honest. Can I get thirty seconds to tell you why I reached out, and you can totally hang up on me if it's not a fit?
guarded_response.note: Disarm with honesty. Thirty-second ask lowers the wall. Smile through it.

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED
permission_rejected.say: Shoot, totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you already know what we do and this just isn't interesting?
permission_rejected.note: This splits the objection. You're looking for whether it's timing or real disinterest. Stay calm and curious.

last_chance_split.label: LAST CHANCE — PLANT THE SEED
last_chance_split.say: Totally fair. If it helps — we actually plug into Track, which I know you guys are running, and a few other coastal operators have been using us to catch stuff in turnover photos their teams were missing. If that ever becomes a priority, I'm easy to find. Really appreciate your time, Amy.
last_chance_split.note: Drop the Track name to show you're not generic. Plant the seed and don't push. Leave the door open.

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER
pain_trigger.say: I was talking to another VP of Ops who runs a pretty similar setup to yours — coastal portfolio, seventy-plus homes, team doing turns every day. Her housekeepers were snapping photos every single turn, uploading them into Track, but honestly nobody had the time to sit there and actually review every photo from every unit. They were basically just CYA photos sitting in a system. And every couple weeks something would slip through — a stain on a sofa, a chipped countertop, a missing set of towels — and the guest would find it before anyone on her team did. And she's the one getting the call from the homeowner.
pain_trigger.note: PAUSE after 'getting the call from the homeowner.' Let the silence work. Amy lives this reality — let her feel it before you say another word.

branches.label: We already have a process for that
Not really a problem for us
I'm not the right person for this

solution_bridge.label: ONE-SENTENCE SOLUTION + CTA
solution_bridge.say: So we built a tool that plugs into the photos your team's already taking — it actually integrates directly with Track — and flags damage, missing items, staging issues automatically. No workflow change for your cleaners at all. Would you be open to taking a look when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue?
solution_bridge.note: One sentence on the product. One sentence CTA. Stop talking. Let her respond.

branches.label: We already have something for that

warm_response.label: THEY'RE WARM — STOP PITCHING
warm_response.say: Awesome — so I don't waste your time with stuff that's not relevant: what does your turnover inspection process actually look like right now? Are your housekeepers the ones taking photos, or do you have inspectors doing a separate pass?
warm_response.note: STOP SELLING. You're in discovery mode. Ask questions, listen, take notes. Her answers tell you exactly how to position the demo.

branches.label: Wants to skip discovery and book

discovery_photo_gap.label: DIG INTO THE PHOTO GAP
discovery_photo_gap.say: Got it. And when those photos come in — is someone actually reviewing every single one? Or is it more like they're there if you need to go back and look after something goes wrong?
discovery_photo_gap.note: This question exposes the core gap. Most teams collect photos but don't review them proactively. Let her admit it.

discovery_track_workflow.label: TRACK-SPECIFIC DISCOVERY
discovery_track_workflow.say: Nice — so you're using Track's housekeeping module for that. How are you finding it for the photo review side? I've heard from a few Track shops that the task management is solid but actually catching stuff in the photos is still pretty manual.
discovery_track_workflow.note: Show you know their stack. This builds credibility and gets her talking about gaps in Track's inspection capability.

branches.label: Says Track works fine for them
Asks how RapidEye connects to Track

discovery_inspector_workflow.label: INSPECTOR WORKFLOW DISCOVERY
discovery_inspector_workflow.say: Interesting — so you've got dedicated inspectors. How many properties can they actually get through in a day? And are they checking every turn or is it more of a spot-check situation?
discovery_inspector_workflow.note: Inspectors are expensive and can't scale. If she has them, the pain is cost or coverage gaps during peak season.

branches.label: Can't cover every turn / spot-check only
Cover every turn but it's expensive

discovery_seasonal.label: SEASONAL PRESSURE
discovery_seasonal.say: That makes sense. What about heading into summer — when you've got back-to-back turns and the volume really ramps up? Does the process hold, or is that when stuff starts slipping through?
discovery_seasonal.note: Cannon Beach summer is their peak season. Back-to-back turns = highest risk for missed issues. This is where manual processes break down.

branches.label: Summer is when things break down

discovery_volume_pressure.label: VOLUME PRESSURE
discovery_volume_pressure.say: That's honestly impressive. How many photos are we talking per turn across eighty-plus homes? That's gotta be a serious volume to actually get through, especially during peak season.
discovery_volume_pressure.note: Put a number on the pain. 80+ homes × photos per turn × summer frequency = thousands of photos weekly. Make the scale tangible.

branches.label: Acknowledges the volume is a lot
Interested in how AI helps with that

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING
book_meeting.say: Love it — let's do this. I've got next Tuesday and Thursday pulled up. Would morning or afternoon work better for a quick fifteen minutes? I can walk you through exactly what it looks like inside Track.
book_meeting.note: Pick specific days. Give a choice of two. Say fifteen minutes — low commitment. Send the invite WHILE on the phone.

branches.label: Not ready to commit to a meeting

meeting_confirmed.label: MEETING BOOKED
meeting_confirmed.say: Perfect — I'm sending the invite right now so it's locked in. Really appreciate you taking my call, Amy. Looking forward to showing you what we've been building. Talk soon.
meeting_confirmed.note: Send the calendar invite immediately. Stop selling. Don't add anything. You got the meeting — get off the phone.

meeting_followup.label: CALENDAR CHECK
meeting_followup.say: Totally — I'll shoot you an email in the next hour with a couple time options. What's the best email for that? Is it a-taylor at meredithlodging dot com?
meeting_followup.note: Confirm her email. Pattern from Aaron Linfoot's email is first-initial + lastname @meredithlodging.com. Lock a follow-up commitment.

branches.label: Says they'll reach out to you

objection_no_budget.label: NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it. Nowadays it's harder to keep a tool, let alone buy something new — especially when everything runs through a parent company like Meredith.
objection_no_budget.note: Agree first. Reference the Meredith parent structure to show you understand their approval chain. Then split.

budget_split.label: BUDGET SPLIT
budget_split.say: Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that budget for this cycle is completely locked, or is it more that anything you try to buy puts you through the ringer with corporate?
budget_split.note: Diagnosing whether it's a real budget wall or an approval process issue. Different answers get different follow-ups.

objection_not_interested.label: NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: I totally get it — I should have assumed you'd be all set. Otherwise you probably would have reached out yourself.
objection_not_interested.note: Agree first. Lower her guard. Then split to understand the real reason.

interest_split.label: INTEREST SPLIT
interest_split.say: Just out of curiosity — is it that this isn't really a problem you're focused on right now, or is it more that you just hate cold calls? Totally fair either way.
interest_split.note: If it's 'hate cold calls,' the door is open for a softer touch. If 'not a problem,' plant the seed and exit.

branches.label: Actually opens up about a problem

objection_have_process.label: ALREADY HAVE A PROCESS
objection_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with eighty-plus homes you'd have to have something dialed in. Especially with the kind of repeat-guest rate you guys have, you can't afford to let stuff slip.
objection_have_process.note: Validate their process. Referencing the ~70% re-book rate from CBVR's website shows you did homework. Then split.

process_split.label: PROCESS SPLIT
process_split.say: Is it that you're fully covered and happy with how things are working, or is it more that switching anything right now with the season coming up would be a headache?
process_split.note: If 'switching is the headache,' the door is open — they're admitting the current process isn't perfect. If truly happy, plant the seed.

branches.label: Switching is the issue / bad timing

test_drive.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
test_drive.say: Totally respect that — you're probably not buying anything right now and that's completely fine. But when budget does free up or summer hits and turns get crazy, the people who move fast are the ones who already know what's on their list. Would you be open to just taking a look — not a commitment, just fifteen minutes so you know what's out there? Worst case you steal some ideas about what other coastal operators are doing with their turnover photos and we part as friends.
test_drive.note: You're selling the meeting, not the product. The meeting itself has value even if she never buys.

objection_send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
objection_send_email.say: Totally fair — I'll send something over. One quick question so it's not just another generic pitch sitting in your inbox: what would actually be most relevant to include? Is it more about how it connects to Track, or more about what other operators your size are seeing in terms of results?
objection_send_email.note: Accept the email ask. But asking what to include extends the conversation and gives you intel for a killer follow-up.

branches.label: Tells you what they care about
Actually, let's just do the call

email_tailored.label: SEND TAILORED EMAIL
email_tailored.say: Perfect — I'll put something together around that and send it over today. What's the best email? Is it a-taylor at meredithlodging dot com? And I'll drop a couple time options in there in case you want to hop on after you've looked it over. Really appreciate your time, Amy.
email_tailored.note: Confirm her email. Include a specific time suggestion in the email. Follow up in 2-3 days if no response. Email pattern is first-initial + lastname @meredithlodging.com.

not_right_person.label: NOT THE RIGHT PERSON
not_right_person.say: Totally fair — who on your team would typically own the inspection side of things? Or is there someone at Meredith corporate who handles tooling decisions for the operations group?
not_right_person.note: Amy may redirect to Rachel Beardslee (Dir of Ops), Aaron Linfoot (President), or Ashley Kingman (GM). Get a name and an intro if possible.

referral_ask.label: REFERRAL DIG
referral_ask.say: Totally understand. Would it be someone like a Director of Operations, or does this kind of thing roll up to someone like Aaron on the executive side? Just want to make sure I'm reaching the right person.
referral_ask.note: Name-drop Aaron Linfoot casually to see if she confirms he's the decision-maker. Shows you know the org. Don't be pushy.

branches.label: Confirms Aaron or gives another name
Won't share / says figure it out
Actually I can take the meeting

referral_get_name.label: GOT A REFERRAL NAME
referral_get_name.say: That's super helpful — really appreciate it. Would it be alright if I mention your name when I reach out to them? That way it doesn't land as another random cold call. I'll make sure it's tailored so it's actually worth their time.
referral_get_name.note: Get permission to use Amy's name. A warm intro is 10x more effective. Log the referral name immediately.

branches.label: Says no / reach out on your own

referral_confirmed.label: REFERRAL LOCKED
referral_confirmed.say: Perfect. Really appreciate you pointing me in the right direction, Amy. I'll reach out to them and keep it relevant. Thanks for your time — enjoy the rest of your day.
referral_confirmed.note: Log the referral. Send outreach within 24 hours mentioning Amy by name if permitted. Don't burn this bridge — Amy may still be involved in the decision.

referral_warm_intro.label: WARM INTRO OFFERED
referral_warm_intro.say: That would be amazing — I really appreciate that. Whatever's easiest for you — an email intro, a quick heads up, anything works. I'll follow up with you so you have my info to pass along. Thanks so much, Amy.
referral_warm_intro.note: Huge win. Send Amy a clean, forwardable email within the hour. Make it easy for her to pass along. Include a brief description and a specific suggested time.

gatekeeper.label: GATEKEEPER
gatekeeper.say: Hey — could you get me through to Amy? It's Sam.
gatekeeper.note: First name only for both of you. No company name. No explanation. Sound like you know her.

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER — CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah — I work with a few other vacation rental operators on the coast. Would you mind letting her know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: A bit more context but still no pitch. Don't explain what RapidEye does. Redirect with the question at the end.

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: Totally understand — we help a couple other property management companies with their turnover inspection workflows. I sent her a note earlier — would you mind just giving her a heads up that Sam Parks is on the line?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: Third attempt. Social proof plus implication you already have a relationship. If this doesn't work, pivot to voicemail or callback time.

gatekeeper_voicemail.label: VOICEMAIL / NOT AVAILABLE
gatekeeper_voicemail.say: No worries at all — when's the best time to catch her? I know things get busy with turns and everything. Or I can leave a quick message if that's easier.
gatekeeper_voicemail.note: Get a callback time if possible. If leaving voicemail, keep it under 20 seconds: 'Hey Amy, Sam Parks — I work with a few other coastal VR operators on their turnover workflows. Thought it'd be worth connecting. I'll try you again Thursday.' Then call back at the suggested time.

branches.label: Gives best time to call back

end_graceful.label: GRACEFUL EXIT
end_graceful.say: Totally understand, Amy. If anything changes, I'm easy to find — Sam Parks, RapidEye. Really appreciate your time. Have a good one.
end_graceful.note: Don't burn the bridge. Log the outcome. Set a follow-up reminder for 3-4 weeks out. She may come around once peak season pressures hit.
